bestBHT.bht: Christ, the Messiah, is described as God over all, blessed forever. This affirms the deity of Christ, emphasizing that he is the true and eternal God, distinct from his human nature. The distinction between his divine and human nature is united within the person of Christ. As the creator, upholder, and governor, he holds supreme authority over angels and mankind. This ascription of praise belongs exclusively to the self-existent, independent Being who is God over all, eternally blessed.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Christ came, who is over all, God—rather, 'God over all.' blessed for ever.
To get rid of the bright testimony... various expedients have been adopted.
It remains then, that we have here no doxology at all... in another respect, 'God over all, blessed for ever.'
Albert Barnes: On this they highly valued themselves, and in a certain sense not unjustly.
The use of this language supposes that there was a higher nature in respect to which he was not of their nation.
If the translation is fairly made, and it has never been proved to be erroneous, it demonstrates that he is God as well as man.
Marvin Vincent: God who is over all be blessed for ever.
John Calvin: It matters not, that this by itself, when separated from the fear of God and holiness of life, is vain and useless.
But we have here a remarkable passage, — that in Christ two natures are in such a manner distinguished, that they are at the same time united in the very person of Christ.
This ascription of praise belongs to none but only to the true and eternal God.
Philip Schaff: As far as concerns the flesh, i.e., His human nature.
The natural connection of this clause is with what precedes...referring to Christ, defining what He is, other than 'according to the flesh.'
The Divinity of Christ is not thereby proven unscriptural; while on the other hand, if the usual view be correct, there is no room for a denial of that doctrine.
Archibald T. Robertson: Who is over all, God blessed for ever (ο ον επ παντων θεος ευλογητος).
A clear statement of the deity of Christ following the remark about his humanity.
John Gill: Whose are the fathers,.... Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob; for, according to the Jewish writers, 'they call none in Israel אבות, 'fathers', but three, and they are Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob; and they call none 'mothers' but four, and they are, Sarah, Rebecca, Rachel, and Leah.'
and of whom, as concerning the flesh, Christ came; that is, either of the fathers, or of the Israelites, from whom Christ, according to his human nature, sprung.
who is described as over all, angels and men, being the creator, upholder, and governor of them; and as having another nature, a divine one, being God, truly and properly God, blessed for evermore.
John Wesley: The original words imply the self-existent, independent Being, who was, is, and is to come.
No words can more clearly express his divine, supreme majesty, and his gracious sovereignty both over Jews and gentiles.
Over all — The supreme; as being God, and consequently blessed for ever.

bhtAttempts.bht: Christ is God over all, blessed for ever. This verse is a clear statement of the deity of Christ, emphasizing that he is not only the Messiah but also the true and eternal God. His divine nature is distinct from his human nature, yet both are united in the person of Christ. As the creator, upholder, and governor of all, Christ holds supreme authority over angels and men. This ascription of praise belongs to none other than the self-existent, independent Being, who is God over all, blessed for evermore.

Christ, who is over all, is God blessed forever. This passage affirms the deity of Christ, emphasizing that he is not only the Messiah but also the true and eternal God. His divine nature, united with his human nature, distinguishes him as the supreme authority over angels and men. This ascription of praise belongs solely to the self-existent, independent Being who is God over all, blessed forevermore.

Christ, as the Messiah, is God over all, blessed forever. This statement confirms the deity of Christ, highlighting that he is not only a human but also the true and eternal God. The distinction between his divine and human nature is profound yet united within the person of Christ. Being the creator, upholder, and governor, he exercises supreme authority over angels and humanity. The praise and adoration conveyed in this statement belong exclusively to the self-existing, independent Being who is God over all, eternally blessed.

Christ, the Messiah, is God over all, blessed forever. This reaffirms his divine nature, emphasizing that he is not just human, but the true and eternal God. The distinction between his divine and human nature is united within Christ himself. As the creator, upholder, and governor of all, he holds supreme authority over angels and humanity. The praise bestowed upon him belongs solely to the self-existent, independent Being who is God over all, eternally blessed.

Christ, the Messiah, is described as God over all, blessed forever. This affirms the deity of Christ, emphasizing that he is the true and eternal God, distinct from his human nature. The distinction between his divine and human nature is united within the person of Christ. As the creator, upholder, and governor, he holds supreme authority over angels and mankind. This ascription of praise belongs exclusively to the self-existent, independent Being who is God over all, eternally blessed.
